description: The lightest and most abundant element in the universe, essential for water and organic compounds.
A light, colorless, odorless noble gas used in balloons, airships, and cryogenics.
appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a red-orange glow when placed in a high-voltage electric field

description: A soft, silvery-white metal widely used in rechargeable batteries and psychiatric medication.
A lightweight but strong alkaline earth metal used in aerospace components and X-ray windows.
A metalloid found in borax, used in heat-resistant glass (Pyrex) and detergents.
The basis of all known life, capable of forming vast chains; forms include charcoal, graphite, and diamond.
A colorless gas making up 78% of Earth's atmosphere, essential for DNA and fertilizers.
A reactive gas essential for respiration and combustion; the most abundant element in Earth's crust.
The most reactive electronegative element, used in toothpaste (fluoride) and Teflon.
An inert noble gas known for its bright red-orange glow in high-voltage discharge lamps.
appearance: colorless gas exhibiting an orange-red glow when placed in a high voltage electric field

description: A soft, reactive metal found in table salt and essential for nerve function and fluid balance.
A light structural metal used in alloys and essential for biological energy production in plants and animals.
A lightweight, corrosion-resistant metal widely used in packaging, construction, and aerospace.
A metalloid semiconductor that is the foundation of modern electronics, computer chips, and glass.
A reactive nonmetal essential for life (DNA, ATP), also used in matches and fertilizers.
appearance: colourless, waxy white, yellow, scarlet, red, violet, black

description: A yellow, brittle nonmetal used in gunpowder, sulfuric acid production, and rubber vulcanization.
A reactive yellow-green gas used for water purification, disinfectants, and making PVC plastic.
An abundant noble gas used in welding, double-glazed windows, and light bulbs to prevent oxidation.
appearance: colorless gas exhibiting a lilac/violet glow when placed in a high voltage electric field

description: A highly reactive metal essential for plant growth (fertilizers) and animal nerve transmission.
An alkaline earth metal essential for bones, teeth, and shell formation; also used in cement.
A rare earth-like metal used in high-strength aluminum alloys for aerospace components and sports equipment.
A strong, lightweight, corrosion-resistant metal used in aerospace, medical implants, and white pigment.
A hard, silvery metal added to steel to improve strength, toughness, and corrosion resistance.
A hard metal used in stainless steel and chrome plating to provide a shiny, corrosion-resistant finish.
A metal crucial for steel production to remove impurities and improve durability; also found in batteries.
A ferromagnetic metal that forms the Earth's core and is the primary component of steel.
appearance: lustrous metallic with a grayish tinge

description: A magnetic metal used in high-strength alloys, powerful magnets, and rechargeable lithium-ion batteries.
A corrosion-resistant metal used in coins, stainless steel, and plating.
appearance: lustrous, metallic, and silver with a gold tinge

description: A reddish metal with excellent electrical and thermal conductivity, used in wiring and plumbing.
A metal primarily used to galvanize steel to prevent rusting and in die-casting alloys.
A soft metal that melts in your hand; used in semiconductors (GaAs) and blue LEDs.
A metalloid semiconductor used in fiber optics, infrared optics, and early transistors.
A toxic metalloid historically used as a poison, but also used in semiconductors and wood preservatives.
A nonmetal used in photocopiers, glass coloring, and as a nutritional supplement.
appearance: black, red, and gray (not pictured) allotropes

description: A reddish-brown liquid halogen used in flame retardants, drilling fluids, and photography.
A noble gas used in high-speed photography flashes and energy-saving fluorescent lamps.
appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a whitish glow in a high electric field

description: A highly reactive alkali metal used in atomic clocks, research, and photocells.
An alkaline earth metal used in red fireworks, flares, and glow-in-the-dark paints.
A transition metal used in red LEDs, phosphors for screens, and superconductors.
A highly corrosion-resistant metal used in nuclear reactors and as synthetic gemstone (cubic zirconia).
A metal used in superconducting magnets for MRI scanners and in high-strength steel alloys.
A metal with a very high melting point, used in high-strength steel, missiles, and lubricants.
The first artificially produced element, radioactive and widely used in medical diagnostic imaging.
A rare platinum-group metal used in wear-resistant electrical contacts and chip resistors.
A rare, highly reflective metal used in catalytic converters and jewelry plating.
A metal used in catalytic converters, electronics, and hydrogen storage and purification.
A precious metal with the highest electrical and thermal conductivity, used in jewelry and electronics.
A toxic metal historically used in NiCd batteries, pigments (yellow/red), and protective coatings.
A soft metal used in touchscreens (Indium Tin Oxide), LCDs, and low-melting solders.
A pliable metal used in solder, plating steel cans, and making bronze alloys.
A brittle metalloid used in flame retardants, lead-acid batteries, and semiconductor alloys.
A metalloid used in solar panels (cadmium telluride), thermoelectric devices, and rewritable discs.
A dark purple halogen used as a medical disinfectant and essential for thyroid hormone production.
appearance: lustrous metallic gray, violet as a gas

description: A heavy noble gas used in ion thrusters for spacecraft, flash lamps, and anesthesia.
appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a blue glow when placed in a high voltage electric field

description: The most reactive metal, used in atomic clocks for precise timekeeping and drilling fluids.
A heavy alkaline earth metal used in medical imaging (barium swallow) and green fireworks.
A rare earth metal used in hybrid car batteries, high-quality camera lenses, and flints.
The most abundant rare earth metal, used in catalytic converters and mischmetal for lighters.
A rare earth metal used in high-strength alloys for aircraft engines and yellow glass coloring.
A rare earth metal famous for creating the strongest permanent magnets found in motors and speakers.
A radioactive rare earth element used in nuclear batteries for pacemakers and guided missiles.
A rare earth metal used in high-temperature magnets and control rods for nuclear reactors.
A rare earth metal used as a phosphor to create red colors in TV screens, monitors, and LEDs.
A magnetic rare earth metal widely used in MRI contrast agents and neutron radiography.
A rare earth metal used in green phosphors for fluorescent lamps and in sonar systems.
A rare earth metal used in high-temperature permanent magnets for electric vehicles and wind turbines.
A rare earth metal with the highest magnetic strength of any element, used in magnets and lasers.
A rare earth metal used in fiber optic amplifiers, dental lasers, and pink glass coloring.
One of the rarest lanthanides, used in portable X-ray machines and high-intensity discharge lamps.
A rare earth metal used in atomic clocks, stainless steel strengthening, and fiber optic lasers.
A dense, expensive rare earth metal used in PET scan detectors and as a catalyst in oil refining.
A corrosion-resistant metal used in nuclear reactor control rods and high-temperature alloys.
A highly corrosion-resistant metal widely used in capacitors for mobile phones and other electronics.
A metal with the highest melting point of all elements, used in light bulb filaments and rocket nozzles.
A dense metal with a high melting point, used in high-temperature superalloys for jet engines.
The densest naturally occurring element, used in fountain pen tips and electrical contacts.
A brittle, extremely corrosion-resistant metal used in high-end spark plugs and crucibles.
A dense, non-reactive precious metal widely used in jewelry, catalytic converters, and lab equipment.
A highly valuable, malleable metal that does not corrode, used in jewelry, currency, and electronics.
A heavy silvery metal that is liquid at room temperature, used in thermometers and fluorescent lamps.
A toxic soft metal historically used in rat poison, now used in electronics and medical imaging.
A dense, toxic metal used in car batteries, radiation shielding, and weights.
A brittle metal with low toxicity, used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals (Pepto-Bismol), and fire sprinklers.
A highly radioactive element discovered by Marie Curie, used in antistatic devices.
One of the rarest natural elements, highly radioactive and used in targeted cancer therapy research.
A radioactive noble gas that naturally accumulates in basements and poses lung cancer risks.
appearance: colorless gas, occasionally glows green or red in discharge tubes

description: An extremely rare and radioactive alkali metal with no commercial uses due to its instability.
A radioactive metal formerly used in glow-in-the-dark paint, now treated with caution.
A radioactive metal that glows blue in the dark, used as a neutron source in research.
appearance: silvery-white, glowing blue in the dark

description: A weakly radioactive metal with potential as a cleaner, more abundant alternative nuclear fuel.
A rare, toxic, radioactive metal usually found in uranium ores, used primarily in research.
A dense radioactive metal used as the primary fuel in nuclear power plants and weapons.
A radioactive metal produced in nuclear reactors, used in detectors and research.
A radioactive metal used in nuclear weapons and as fuel for spacecraft generators (RTGs).
appearance: silvery white, tarnishing to dark gray in air

description: A synthetic radioactive metal widely used in small amounts in household smoke detectors.
A highly radioactive metal used as a power source for space missions and in alpha particle X-ray spectrometers.
appearance: silvery metallic, glows purple in the dark

description: A radioactive synthetic element used mainly for synthesizing heavier elements.
A strong neutron emitter used in metal detectors, oil well logging, and cancer treatment.
A synthetic element discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb test; used in research.
A synthetic element produced in nuclear explosions, usable only in scientific research.
A synthetic radioactive element named after the creator of the periodic table, Dmitri Mendeleev.
A synthetic radioactive element named after Alfred Nobel, existing only for seconds in labs.
A synthetic radioactive element that concludes the actinide series; of research interest only.
A synthetic radioactive element named after physicist Ernest Rutherford, with a very short half-life.
A highly radioactive synthetic element named after the research town of Dubna, Russia.
A synthetic element named after Glenn Seaborg; one of the first elements named after a living person.
A synthetic radioactive element named after physicist Niels Bohr, with no commercial application.
A highly radioactive synthetic element named after the German state of Hesse.
A synthetic element named after physicist Lise Meitner, produced only in tiny amounts.
A synthetic element named after Darmstadt, Germany; it decays within microseconds.
A synthetic radioactive element named after Wilhelm Röntgen, discoverer of X-rays.
A synthetic element named after Nicolaus Copernicus, with extremely short-lived isotopes.
A synthetic element and the first to be discovered by Asian scientists (RIKEN institute, Japan).
A synthetic superheavy element named after the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions in Russia.
A highly radioactive synthetic element named after the Moscow region.
A synthetic element named after Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California.
A synthetic halogen named after the state of Tennessee, known for its nuclear research contributions.
The heaviest element currently known, a synthetic noble gas named after physicist Yuri Oganessian.
